chemicals.name: Water
chemicals.about: Water is a transparent, tasteless, odorless, and nearly colorless chemical substance.
chemicals.mechanism: Water molecules form hydrogen bonds with each other, creating its unique properties.
chemicals.uses: Water is essential for life, used in various industrial processes, and as a solvent in chemistry.
chemicals.effects: Consuming inadequate amounts of water can lead to dehydration and various health issues.

chemicals.name: Carbon Dioxide
chemicals.about: Carbon dioxide is a colorless gas with a density about 53% higher than that of dry air.
chemicals.mechanism: Carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas and contributes to global warming by trapping heat in the Earth's atmosphere.
chemicals.uses: Carbon dioxide is used in carbonation of beverages, fire extinguishers, and as a refrigerant.
chemicals.effects: Excessive levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere contribute to climate change and ocean acidification.

chemicals.name: Oxygen
chemicals.about: Oxygen is a chemical element with the symbol O and atomic number 8. It is a member of the chalcogen group in the periodic table.
chemicals.mechanism: Oxygen is essential for respiration in aerobic organisms and plays a vital role in combustion processes.
chemicals.uses: Oxygen is used in medical applications, metal cutting, welding, and various industrial processes.
chemicals.effects: Oxygen deficiency can lead to hypoxia, while excessive oxygen levels can lead to oxygen toxicity.

chemicals.name: Sodium Chloride
chemicals.about: Sodium chloride is the chemical name for salt. It occurs naturally in many parts of the world as the mineral halite.
chemicals.mechanism: Sodium chloride dissociates into sodium and chloride ions in water, making it a strong electrolyte.
chemicals.uses: Sodium chloride is used as a seasoning, food preservative, and in various industrial processes.
chemicals.effects: Excessive consumption of sodium chloride can lead to high blood pressure and other health issues.

chemicals.name: Hydrogen Peroxide
chemicals.about: Hydrogen peroxide is a pale blue liquid, slightly more viscous than water. It is a weak acid.
chemicals.mechanism: Hydrogen peroxide decomposes into water and oxygen gas, releasing oxygen when it comes into contact with catalase enzyme.
chemicals.uses: Hydrogen peroxide is used as a disinfectant, bleaching agent, and in rocket propulsion.
chemicals.effects: Concentrated hydrogen peroxide can cause irritation, burns, and is corrosive to organic tissues.
